Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Elucidating the Geologic Record of Late Paleozoic Subduction Initiation Along the Southwestern Margin of Laurentia, Southern California and Sonora, Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration: The principle aim of this project is to document the timing and response of the southwestern Laurentian margin to the initiation of subduction during late Paleozoic time. Although the recycling of lithosphere at subduction zones is a fundamental part of plate tectonic theory, the manner by which subduction zones initiate is a poorly constrained process, largely because there are few modern examples and ancient examples are largely not recognized or well preserved. Unique sequences of sedimentary and volcanic rocks exposed in southern California (El Paso Mountains region) and northern Mexico (Carborca Block) will be investigated in order to better understand how subduction inception is recorded in stratigraphic successions and how the paleogeography of continental margins evolves in response to the onset of plate convergence. We propose that continental margin successions recording subduction initiation will have predictable deepening and shallowing trends and distinct changes in sand composition and detrital zircon provenance through time reflecting the changing paleogeography of source regions. An additional geochemical and geochronologic investigation of volcanic sequences and coeval intrusions will be used to constrain the timing and petrogenesis of magmatic products, which we suggest will record conditions unique to cold, nascent continental arc settings. Results of this project may contribute significantly to global models of the birth and development of subduction zones. This project is a multi-disciplinary and collaborative effort between researchers at California State University - Northridge and Northern Arizona University, which are both minority-serving institutions. In addition to the science goals of the project, this research will provide training and mentorship for masters level and undergraduate students and promote the involvement of underrepresented groups in STEM research. Sample collections and study results will be used for the development of resources for teaching, community outreach, and further research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTRODUCTION: The recycling of lithosphere at subduction zones is one of the most fundamental aspects of plate tectonic theory, yet the initiation of subduction at newly convergent margins is poorly understood. This is because the onset of subduction does not get preserved well in the rock record and because modern analogs are few. A unique suite of Permian igneous and metasedimentary rocks, preserved in southern California and Sonora, Mexico, are thought to record the initiation of subduction along the southwestern margin of North America. These rocks were investigated in order to more precisely constrain the development, growth and surficial expression of a nascent subduction zone. The specific questions addressed were: 1) how is the initiation of subduction recorded in the stratigraphic record?; 2) how does the paleogeography of continental margins evolve in response to the development of subduction zones?; and 3) how can incipient subduction be recognized in early arc-magmatic products?

NEW FINDINGS / INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Research performed by PIs and their students at California State University-Northridge (CSUN) primarily focused on the analysis of Permian metasedimentary strata and coeval plutonic rocks in the El Paso Mountains and surrounding region, southern California. Mapping and stratigraphic work indicate that the Permian metasedimentary rocks record an upsection change from deposition in a continental slope / base of slope environment at the bottom to a shallower, arc-proximal marine setting near the top. The latter likely reflects the development of a forearc basin immediately following subduction initiation. Provenance analysis of Permian sandstones indicates that the lower part of the section was sourced from interior North America with an additional significant contribution of detritus from an enigmatic, highly evolved source (initial εHf as low as -22), with Paleozoic ages (330-280 Ma) not commonly recorded in the North American Cordillera. Detrital zircon results show a shift in provenance near the top of the section, with sandstones yielding unimodal age peaks that overlap, both in age and isotopic character, with local arc plutons. This is interpreted as marking the onset of subduction-related arc magmatism that generated a topographic barrier cutting off older sources to the east.

Investigation of Late Permian to Triassic plutons in the El Paso Mountains region revealed that arc magmatism began as early as ca. 274 Ma, almost 20 m.y. before the previously interpreted initiation of subduction (Fig. 1A). One particularly interesting finding of our work is the observation that the first arc intrusions are the most isotopically evolved and become increasingly primitive into the early to middle Triassic (Fig. 1B).  This trend is interpreted as reflecting a change in upper plate stress conditions over time. In our preferred model, subduction initiates due to contractional forcing, which leads to shortening in the upper plate and the involvement of supracrustal materials in early melts. This is followed by a change to more oblique convergence, which promotes transtension and the generation of more voluminous, primarily mantle-derived magmas.

BROADER IMPACTS: This project has had a significant impact on several students at CSUN. It supported theses by MS student Eric McDonald and BS student Mary Ann Ferrer, both of whom graduated in 2016 and are working in STEM fields. Ferrer is second author on a manuscript related to dating of igneous rocks in the El Paso Mountains region, which is in press at GSA Bulletin. CSUN BS student John Lightburn was also supported by this project and expects to graduate in 2018. All students received extensive training both in the field and in various laboratories. They also benefited from close collaboration with the working group at Northern Arizona University (NAU). For example, Eric McDonald helped NAU MS student Steve Dobbs with field work in Sonora, Mexico and Dobbs spent a week at CSUN working with PI Marsaglia, who served on his MS thesis. Additionally, CSU-Northridge stratigraphy students (~ 18) participated in a field trip to the El Paso Mountains where they received training in mapping and section-measuring in the context of a broader research project. Results from their field work was incorporated into McDonald?s thesis. Materials and geochemical datasets from the plutonic suite are being incorporated into a lab assignment for an Earth Materials course taught by PI Cecil every year. In addition to the impact that this project has had on students at CSUN, it also helped to propel the research program of PI Cecil and has led to a new collaboration with a USGS group mapping in the Lane Mountain region of southern California. As a result, PI Cecil is now a co-author on a forthcoming map and an Open-File Report from that group.
